Description: A large depression formed when a volcano’s summit or magma chamber collapses after a major eruption.
A small, steep conical hill built from volcanic fragments (scoria) erupted from a single vent.
Plural form of cinder cone – small volcanoes composed of pyroclastic fragments around a vent.
A generic term for a volcanic cone formed by ejected fragments around a vent.
A volcanic cone formed largely of pumice fragments (light, vesicular rock) ejected during eruption.
A cone built from pyroclastic material (ash, lapilli, bombs) around a vent.
Plural of pyroclastic cone – multiple small cones built from explosively ejected fragments.
A small volcanic cone composed of scoria (vesicular basaltic fragments) around a vent.
Plural of scoria cone – many small cones of scoria in a volcanic field.
A volcanic cone formed primarily by viscous lava piling up near the vent rather than flowing far.
A rounded mound formed by highly viscous lava extruding slowly, building up near the vent.
Plural of lava dome – multiple such structures in a volcanic region.
A line of craters formed along fissures or aligned vents producing multiple craters.
A crater formed by explosive activity, often shallow, sometimes from phreatic interactions.
A linear crack in the crust through which lava erupts, often forming a row of vents.
Plural of fissure vent – multiple vents along cracks releasing lava or gas.
A region with multiple volcanic centres and varied volcanic structures, erupting over time.
A non‐single edifice area of volcanic activity – many vents & volcanoes across an area.
A broad, shallow crater formed by explosive interaction of magma with groundwater (phreatomagmatic).
Plural of maar – several such craters often in volcanic fields.
A volcanic cone formed by explosive interaction of magma and water, with fine‐grained tuff deposits.
Ring‐shaped volcanic features formed by phreatomagmatic explosions producing broad, shallow craters.
An area where volcanic gases and steam escape through surface vents, without major lava flows.
A zone of geothermal activity (hot springs, steam vents) often linked with volcanic systems.
A surface feature where mud, water and gas vent from the subsurface; not always magmatic in origin.
Indicates the feature is classified as non‐volcanic (not a true volcanic edifice).
Indicates the volcano type is not determined or classified.
Broad, gently‐sloping volcano built by low‐viscosity lava flows over long periods.
Same as 'Shield' – a volcano with broad profile from many fluid lava flows.
Plural of shield volcano – multiple broad volcanoes, often in hotspot settings.
A rare type of shield volcano built mostly from pyroclastic flows rather than fluid lava.
A volcano with multiple vents and edifice structures, showing mixed behaviours over time.
A volcanic edifice made up of two or more overlapping volcanoes or vents.
A stratovolcano whose summit is partially filled by a younger cone – often has a nested crater.
A tall, conical volcano built by many layers of hardened lava, tephra, and volcanic ash.
Alternate naming for stratovolcano – a steep-sided composite volcano.
Plural form of stratovolcano.
A volcano erupted beneath ice or a glacier, creating unique geomorphology.
A volcano whose edifice is wholly or partly beneath the sea surface.
Same as 'Submarine' – underwater/partly underwater volcanic edifice.
Probably indicates uncertainty whether the feature is submarine; essentially underwater volcano.
Plural of submarine volcano – many underwater volcanoes.
